anon 0.0.0.9000
  • Reference

Anonymization Functions

anon_fns.Rd

A collection of functions for anonymizing different types of data.

Usage

anon_fns

Format

A list containing the following anonymization functions:

date_shift

Shifts dates while preserving relative relationships

email

Anonymizes email addresses while preserving email-like structure

id_chr_sequence

Converts unique identifiers to sequential character IDs

id_num_sequence

Converts unique identifiers to sequential numeric IDs

num_preserve_distribution

Anonymizes numeric data while preserving distribution

num_range

Converts numeric values to range categories

phone_number

Anonymizes phone numbers with sequential fake numbers

date_shift

Shifts dates to a new time period while preserving relative relationships between dates. Supports both Date and POSIXct objects.

Parameters:

x

Date or POSIXct vector to shift

center_date

New center point for the date range (default: current date)

scramble

Logical, whether to scramble dates while preserving intervals

email

Anonymizes email addresses by replacing them with sequential fake emails, only affecting strings that look like email addresses.

Parameters:

x

Character vector potentially containing email addresses

start

Username prefix for generated emails (default: "user")

domain

Domain for generated emails (default: "domain.com")

id_chr_sequence

Converts unique values to sequential character identifiers with customizable formatting.

Parameters:

x

Vector of values to anonymize

scramble

Logical, whether to randomize the assignment order

start

Character prefix for generated IDs (default: "ID ")

padding

Logical, whether to zero-pad numbers for consistent width

padding_chr

Character used for padding (default: "0")

id_num_sequence

Converts unique values to sequential numeric identifiers.

Parameters:

x

Vector of values to anonymize

scramble

Logical, whether to randomize the assignment order

num_preserve_distribution

Anonymizes numeric data while preserving distributional properties using various transformation methods.

Parameters:

x

Numeric vector to anonymize

method

Transformation method: "rank", "noise", or "quantile"

...

Additional method-specific parameters:

- noise_sd: Standard deviation for noise method

- dist_family: Distribution family for quantile method ("normal", "uniform", "exponential")

num_range

Converts numeric values into range categories, either preserving actual ranges or creating anonymized range labels.

Parameters:

x

Numeric vector to categorize

n_breaks

Number of range categories to create (default: 5)

method

Method for creating breaks: "equal_width" or "equal_count"

clean_breaks

Logical, whether to use pretty break points

scramble

Logical, whether to randomize range label assignment

keep_values

Logical, whether to keep actual range values or use generic labels

phone_number

Anonymizes phone numbers by replacing them with sequential fake phone numbers in 555-xxxx format, only affecting strings that match phone number patterns.

Parameters:

x

Character vector potentially containing phone numbers

Examples

# Character ID sequence
ids <- c("A123", "B456", "A123", "C789")
anon_fns$id_chr_sequence(ids)
#> [1] "ID 1" "ID 2" "ID 1" "ID 3"

# Email anonymization
emails <- c("john@company.com", "not_an_email", "jane at work dot org")
anon_fns$email(emails)
#> [1] "user001@domain.com" "not_an_email"       "user002@domain.com"

# Numeric range categorization
values <- c(150, 165, 180, 175, 160, 190)
anon_fns$num_range(values, n_breaks = 3)
#> [1] "[150,160)" "[160,170)" "[180,190]" "[170,180)" "[160,170)" "[180,190]"

# Date shifting
dates <- as.Date(c("2023-01-15", "2023-02-20", "2023-03-10"))
anon_fns$date_shift(dates, center_date = "2024-06-01")
#> [1] "2024-05-02" "2024-06-07" "2024-06-25"
